results.content: The instructor has great knowledge and skill in the topic for this course. He teaches the topic first, then gives you a practice project that he works through with you. Some of the things I did not like about this course were that the instructor codes VERY fast and I had to do a lot of pausing just to keep up with him. There was also a class he wrote which he completely left out of the videos. The only way to get it is to download his source code and copy it into your project. Lastly, I hate automapper and he used it. No matter what I tried, I couldn't get automapper to work properly, so when mapper 1 object type to another, it failed. I looked over my object classes and they were the same as his, but mine would never work. So I could never get a finished product on my code. The instructor helped some other students who also struggled with automapper, but even those fixes didn't solve my problems. Rather than go through even more trouble to simply even get it working, I just gave up. I was 96% through the course when I just couldn't take it anymore. I ran his source code and it wouldn't run. It said there were build errors and showed 0 errors in the error window of visual studio. Rather than look into the issues behind it, I just decided to not take that extra time and move on. Again, the professor is very knowledgable and does a good job overall. I just didn't like his speed, leaving class completely out of the videos and the crazy bugs with automapper.

results.content:
Just finished the course. Let us go one by one. Course content is great, if you are new and do not know anything about MVC then great way to start. Each lessons are explained with small stand alone applications so that even if you are stuck in one you can come back and start new lesson without break. (I have scene courses where just to explain new concept people say "import dll built in lesson 6 (what if lesson 6 was not completed by you? One have to go all the way to build that dll and come back to current lesson"). So no tight coupling :-)

Now coming to project included. It is a basic project but Author has used everything that is used in professional ones. Be it dependencies, repositories, packages, third party tools (automapper,Unity for DI) etc. So if you understand the flow then you can grasp any project at your workplace. (Not specifically MVC apps, but most window, web apps follow similar design and data flow).

Coming to Cons (My reason for deducting half star)..

1. I feel that we can avoid Jquery/Javascript codes in calling apis. It is good for intermediates but a complete beginner looses his/her interest. Also some hiding /displaying things are achieved through scripts. (but trust me it is very small part, it wont effect anyone's learning.)

2. Use of AutoMapper. I know the tool is excellent, but it's new version (9.0.0 or something) is not that helpful and fails randomely. So for a beginner it is tough to understand the error and solve it, and this is where most students loose interest in the course. It took me a whole night to reverse engineer the project and build it without AutoMapper. (This is when I came to know how useful the tool is). However There could be one small lecture included that how can u map ViewModel to Model or vice Versa without Auto Mapper. That would be helpful for beginners.

3. Project lecture ends abruptly after "Create a question". Edit and Delete questions are skipped. Author could have given those as assignments with code and hints. (Again this is a personal view not a flaw in course, because by this lecture you will be knowledgeable enough to do this.)

Overall a great course.

Thanks

results.content:
I would highly recommend to opt for this course because of sample project. Harsh has typed and explained every line of code  that is required to create stack overflow type project from scratch. I learned many things after going over sample project sessions. Pace of lecture was bit fast at the beginning, I had to play it for .75 speed, but towards end of course, for sample project sessions, the pace is fine.

Harsh, you are an excellent teacher, my only suggestion is to add diagrams wherever possible, it will give an extra edge for your teaching!
Though you have explained every code in Sample project, it could have been even better with some diagrams in between to quickly visualize what we are planning to do upfront. 
For example-1: Diagram that explains interaction of Repository, Service, DataModel and ViewModels
example-2: Diagram that shows UI design before creating UI layout pages etc
There is a saying - a diagram is a worth thousand words.

I am definitely going to learn from you from all your other courses :-)

results.content: I had first purchased this course around 3 yrs back. I found the content to be quite good, but suggested a few improvements in the delivery.  I revisited the course to refresh my skills a few months back and found that Harsha had covered up on most of the areas of improvement which I had noticed earlier.  The content and delivery is even more refined now,  Great course for serious learners.  No distractions and ever focused. Content is great and organized very well.  Though it's lengthy, covering even a part of this course will give you years of experience in the subject.  The experience and advanced skill level of Harsha shows throughout.  I never was able to finish the whole course, but half way through itself I had developed the required confidence.  GREAT EFFORT HARSHA.  And most importantly Harsha is all ears to your doubts and questions.  So I am happy that he guided me with timely advice whenever I reached out to him via Udemy's platform.

results.content:
First of all I would like to thank Harsha for explaining MVC 5 concepts in depth. He is definitely very very knowledgeable on this subject. His style of explaining the concept first and then moving to code writing helps understand the code much better. He explains every action that the code takes, as the code action moves from one part of the code to the other. This way you know exactly what your code does and why. I look forward to building new projects using Asp.Net MVC 5.
Note that in the beginning you may find his style like a college classroom and monotonous. But trust me if you get used to it and practice along, you have a TON to learn here.
